p.seg: The Master said,
"Having studied something to exercise it in practice, at the proper times,
isn't that satisfying?
To have a colleague come from a distant region
isn't that delightful?
When others do not appreciate one not to feel offended
isn't that behaving in a gentlemanly fashion?"
Yǒuzi said,
"That anyone whose personality is both filial and fraternal and yet should be prone to offend the authorities,
that is quite rare.
For someone not prone to offending superiors yet to be prone to creating political rebellions,
that never occurs.
The gentleman concentrates his efforts on what is basic.
Once what is basic is established, then the Way will [naturally] emerge.
As for filial piety and fraternal love (in general),
these must count as the basis for Goodness, mustn't they?"
The Master said,
"Those who make their speech crafty and their appearance artificially distinguished
are rarely indeed Good."
Zēngzǐ said,
"I daily investigate my person in a threefold manner:
When counselling others in planning have I failed to do my loyal best ?
In my dealings with friends have I failed to show good faith?
What has been passed on to me, have I failed to exercise it in practice?
The Master said,
"In guiding a large state with a thousand war chariots,
carry out your official tasks with respectful diligence and be trustworthy,
be sparing with your use of resources and take loving care of others,
Employ the people at the right times."
The Master said,
"A proper student,
when with his family, will be filial
and when abroad will show proper humility towards elders .
He will be diligent and he should be trustworthy,
and will show general loving concern for the masses, but seek proximity with those who are Good.
If his actions leave him with surplus energy
then he will devote himself to the polite arts."
Zixià said,
"If for someone worthiness is as attractive as female beauty,
if in serving his father and mother he is able to use up all his strength,
and in serving his ruler he is able to give everything he has,
and if in his dealings with friends he shows good faith in everything he promises,
then even if it be said that he is has not yet engaged in proper study,
I'm bound to say that he has engaged in proper study/is learned."
The Master said,
"If a man of superior character does not cultivate moral weight he will not have political authority,
[but] if he is devoted to study he will not be inflexible.
One must make devoted effort and good faith one's main concern,
one must not cultivate the personal friendship of any who are not as good as oneself,
and when you have made a mistake do not shrink from mending your ways."
Zēngzi said:
"If one is careful about the end,
and if one follows up the distant ones,
then the basic integrity of the people will revert to its natural abundance."
Ziqin asked Zigòng:
"When our Master gets to such-and-such a country
he is bound to learn about that country's administration.
Is this because he is seeking to find this out
or do they just give him the information?"
Zigòng replied:
"Our Master shows himself mild, decent, respectful, frugal and deferential so as to achieve his aims.
As for the Master seeking this,
this is somehow different from other people's seeking it, isn't it?"
The Master said:
"While his father is alive
observe his aspirations;
when is father is no more
observe his behaviour.
If for three years he in no way tries to introduce improvements to his father's ways of behaviour
that may properly be called filial piety.
Yǒuzǐ said:
"In the deployment of ritual
harmony is the noblest thing;
in the Way of the Former Kings
this is the most beautiful thing.
In matters small and large they took it (harmony) as their starting point,
but there were things they would not do.
Understanding harmony then to go on to be (simply) harmonious
without tempering harmony with ritual propriety
that is still something one should not undertake to do."
Yǒuzi said:
"If one's good faith is close to rectitude
one's proposals/promises bear repeating;
if one's politeness is close to riual propriety,
one will keep public shame and humiliation at bay.
If one marries one who has not failed her close of kin,
then she can be made a member of one's own lineage.
The Master said:
"A gentleman in dining out should never seek surfeit,
when staying at home he should not seek comfort,
he should be nimble in the performance of tasks and careful about public commitments,
he cultivates the proximity of those who have obtained the Way to have himself corrected by them.
Then he should definitely be called "fond of study".
Zigòng said:
"When poor, one should never indulge in flattery,
when rich one should never indulge in arrogance.
What about this (saying)?"
The Master said:
"That is acceptable.
But this is still not quite as good as someone who being poor is full of joy,
and being rich is preoccupied by ritual propriety."
Zǐgòng said:
"As the Ode has it:
'As if carved, as if polished,
as if cut, as if ground.'
Does this perhaps apply to what we have just been saying?"
The Master said:
"As for our friend Sì
one can definitely begin to seriously discuss the Songs with him!
One tells him one thing and he knows whatever will come next."
The Master said:
"I'm not concerned about others not properly appreciate me.
I'm concerned that I do not properly appreciate others."
The Master said:
"If one conducts an administration through inner moral power
one is like the North Star:
It constantly stays in its proper place and the various stars bow to it."
The Master said:
"The Songs are three hundred in number,
but one phrase will cover these.
It runs:
"Lo, never be wayward!""
The Master said:
"If one guides them through administrative measures,
if one gets them to toe the line through punishments,
then the people will try to avoid these things and be without shame;
if one guides them through inner moral power,
if one gets them to toe the line through ritual propriety,
they will have a sense of shame, and more over they will straighten themselves out ."
The Master said:
"By the age of fifteen my ambition was for study.
By the age of thirty I had taken my stand.
By the age of forty I was not confused.
By the age of fifty I understood what was ordained by Heaven.[1]
By the age of sixty my ears were attuned.
By the age of seventy, when I followed my heart's desires
I would not overstep the rules."
Mèng Yìzǐ asked about filial piety.
The Master said:
"It is that one should never be disobedient."
When Fán Chi was driving the chariot
the master reported this to him:
"Mèngsūn asked me about filial piety.
I replied politely:
'It is not to be disobedient.'"
Fán Chi said:
"What did you mean?"
The Master said:
"While they are alive one serves them according to ritual propriety;
When they die, one buries them according to ritual propriety,
and one sacrifices to them according to ritual propriety."
Mèng Wǔbó asked about filial piety.
The Master said:
"It is when one's father and mother only have one's acute illnesses to worry about."
Zǐyóu asked about filial piety.
The Master said:
"As for filial piety these days,
this refers to being able to nourish.
But when it comes to dogs and horses
they are all able to have those they take proper care of and nourish.
If one is not showing proper respect,
whereby is one to make the distinction?"
Zǐxià asked about filial piety.
The Master said:
"The spirit displayed<1> is the difficult point.
If when there is something to be done
then the juniors will take on the work;
if when there is wine or food
elders get to eat their fill,
should one ever consider such behaviour as filial?
The Master said:
"When I discuss things with Huí
for a whole day he does not once disagree,
as if he was stupid.
But after he leaves he examines his personal life,
and then he surely is in a position to deploy his skills.
Huí is not stupid."
The Master said:
"Look at what he takes as his reasons,
observe what he follows,
investigate where he finds his peace.
Where can the man hide?
Where can the man hide?"
The Master said:
"If one is warmly familiar with the old and understand the recent
one may become a teacher."
The Master said:
"The gentleman does not conduct himself as an instrument [for others to use]."
Zǐgòng asked about the superior man.
The Master said:
"He is the first to act on his pronouncements, and then, afterwards, goes on to act in their spirit." Roderick Whitfield: "He first marshals his words, and then acts accordingly."
The Master said:
"The gentleman is catholic and not partial;
the small man is partial and not catholic."
The Master said:
"If one studies without reflecting then one gets trapped;
if one reflects without studying one is embarking on a dangerous course."
The Master said:
If one devotes ones energies to divergent approaches
then this will indeed definitely bring harm!
The Master said:
"Yóu!
I will teach you to understand things.
When you understand something consider that you understand it;
when you do not understand something, consider that you do not understand it.
In such a way you will understand."
Zǐzhāng was studying in order to seek a position with official rewards attached.
The Master said:
"Learn broadly and suspend judgment on what is doubtful,
speak carefully about what remains,
then you will make few mistakes.
See much but suspend judgment on what is dangerous,
act carefully regarding the rest
then you will have few regrets.
If in one's public pronouncements one makes few mistakes
and in action you have few regrets
there is a reward in this in itself."
Duke Āi asked:
"What must one do for the people in general to fulfil their functions obediently?"
Confucius replied politely:
"If one promotes those who are straight and sets aside all those who are warped
then the people will fulfil their functions obediently.
If one promotes those who are warped and sets aside all those who are straight
then the people will not fulfil their functions obediently."
Jì Kāngzǐ asked:
"In order to make the people respectful and prepared to do their best for one, so as to encourage them
what is one to do?"
The Master said:
"Approach them with dignified seriousness,
then they will be respectful;
show filial piety and parental love,
then they will do their loyal best for you;
if one promotes the good and instructs the incompetent,
then they will feel encouraged."
Somebody said to Confucius:
"Why are you not running a government?"
The Master said:
"In the Documents it says,
'It is a matter of filial piety! It is indeed a matter of filial piety,
and of cultivating friendly relations with one's brothers,
one may have an impact on those who run the government.'
This is also working at government.
Why should I go on to work at government?"
The Master said:
"If a person lacks good faith
then I do not know what is acceptable about him.
If a large vehicle doesn't have its large cross-bar at the end of the carriage pole
or if a small vehicle doesn't have its small cross-bar,
how can one make these proceed?"
Zǐzhāng asked:
"Can one understand matters ten generations ago?"
The Master said:
"The Yīn based themselves on the rituals of the Xià,
and what they subtracted and added
can be understood;
the Zhōu based themselves on the Yīn rituals,
and what they subtracted and added
can be understood.
Presumably, as long as someone/anyone continues the Zhōu tradition,
then even matters a hundred generations ago can be understood."
The Master said:
"To sacrifice to other than the right kind of ghost
To see what is right but not to do it
that is lack of courage."
Confucius, referred to the Jì clan, saying:
"Eight rows of dancers dancing in the main hall:
if such a thing is bearable,
then what is not bearable?"
The Three Families removed the sacrificial offerings to the yǒng music.
The Master said:
"'Attending are the lords,
The Son of Heaven in his great splendour.'
How can one pick these lines in the halls of the Three Families?
The Master said:
"As for a person who is not Good,
how can he be in accordance with ritual propriety?
As for a person who is not Good,
how can he be live up to the ideals expressed in music?
Lín Fàng asked about the basis of ritual practice.
The Master said:
"A large question indeed!
As for ritual practice
rather than being lavish
one should be economic;
in the practice of funeral arrangements,
rather than being nonchalant
one should show grief."
The Master said:
"When the barbarians have a ruler
they are no match for the various Xià peoples without a ruler."
The Jì were sacrificing at Tàishān.
The Master said to Rǎn Yǒu:
"Can't you manage to save them from engaging in this?"
Rǎn Yǒu replied politely:
"I cannot."
The Master said:
"Alas !
Would one ever think Tàish1ān ever be inferior to Lín Fàng [in knowledge of the rites]?"
The Master said:
"The gentleman competes in nothing.
And if he has to, it is surely in archery!
Bowing politely and yielding to everyone, he walks up,
and going down he salutes everyone with wine.
Even as he competes he still behaves as a gentleman."
Zǐxià asked:
"'The artful smile charming,
the beautiful eyes well-defined,
the plain surface on which to make a beautiful pattern.'
What does this mean?"
The Master said:
"The work of drawing comes after the plain surface."
He said: "Does ritual come afterwards?"
The Master said:
"The person who inspires me, personally, is Shāng!
One can definitely exchange views on the Songs with him."
The Master said:
"As for the ritual of the Xià,
I can speak up on it.
But Qí does not provide sufficient evidence.
As for the ritual of the Yīn,
I can speak of it.
But Sòng does not provide sufficient evidence.
This is because the written materials and the worthies are not sufficient in number.
Had they been sufficient,
I would have been able to provide good evidence."
The Master said:
"The dì sacrifice, whatever happens from the libation onwards,
I simply to not want to witness it."
Somebody asked about the explanation of the dì sacrifice.
The Master said:
"I don't understand it properly.
If anyone understood it properly, he could deal with the whole world
like showing it up here!"
And he pointed to his palm.
Sacrifice to the ancestors as if they were present.
Sacrifice to the spirits as if the spirits were present.
The Master said:
"When one does not join a sacrifice,
it is as if one had not sacrificed."
Wángsūn Jiǎ asked:
"'Rather than paying polite homage to the household shrine
it is better to pay polite homage to the kitchen god.'
What does that mean?"
The Master said:
"That is not right.
If one falls foul of Heaven
there is no one can turn to in prayer."
The Master said:
"The Zhōu looked back upon two dynasties.
How impressive their elegance was!
I follow the Zhōu."
When the Master entered the Great Temple
then about every matter he would have questions.
Someone said:
"How could one ever imagine that this son of a man of Zōu understood ritual propriety?
When he enters the Great Temple
then about every matter he will have questions.
The Master heard about this
and he said:
"That is the kind of thing ritual propriety is about!"
The Master said:
"In archery one does not take the state of the leather in the aim as the main thing.
This is because the strength of people is not of the same order.
That is the way of the ancients."
Zǐgòng would have liked to dispense with the live goat at the Announcement of the New Month.
The Master said:
"My dear friend Zǐgòng,
you prefer your goat,
I prefer my ritual propriety."
The Master said:
"If in serving one's (own) ruler one pays exhaustive attention to ritual propriety
people imagine that one is engaging in sycophancy."
Duke Dìng asked:
"As for a ruler deploying his ministers.
and a minister serving his ruler,
how is one to go about these things?"
Confucius replied politely:
"The ruler should deploy the ministers according to ritual propriety
and the ministers should serve the ruler with due loyal effort."
The Master said:
"The Guānjū
is joyful without being extravagant,
mournful without being hurtful."
Duke Āi asked Zǎiwǒ about the altars of the land.
Zǎiwǒ replied politely:
The Xià used the pine,
the Yīn people used the cypress,
and the Zhou people used the chestnut
saying
it makes the people 'trembling and fearful'."
When the Master heard about this he commented:
"Matters that are completed one does not explain,
matters that have gone their proper course one does not remonstrate on,
what is past one does not censure."
The Master said:
"Guǎnzhòng's format is so small!"
Someone asked:
"Was Guǎnzhòng stingy?"
Confucius said:
"Guǎn had three residences,
and the duties of his employees did not overlap.
How could he get to count as stingy?"
"Does Guǎnzhòng understand ritual?
He said:
"The ruler of the land established screens in front of his gate,
and Guǎnzhòng also established screens in front of his gate.
The ruler of the land, in order to cultivate the relations betwen two rulers
owned a stand for tipping over vessels for drink,
and Guǎnzhòng likewise acquired a stand for tipping over vessels for drink.
If Guǎnzhòng understands ritual,
then who does not understand ritual?
The Master was in conversation with the Grand Music Master of Lǔ about music,
and he said (surely impertinently encroaching on the other man's speciality!):
"Musical performance is surely something one can come to understand.
When it starts to be played
it is all in unison;
as it goes on
it is all pure,
it is all shining,
it is all amply mellifluous,
and thus it achieves itself."
The border guard at Yí asked for an interview
and said:
"When a superior man comes here,
I never fail to get an interview."
One of Confucius' followers introduced him.
When he had left, Confucius commented:
"My dear friends, why worry about losing out?
The world has been without the Way for a long time.
Is Heaven wanting to make a wooden bell-clapper of your Master?"
The Master said about the Shào:
"It is consummately beautiful,
and moreover it is consummately excellent."
Referring to the Wǔ:
"It is consummately beautiful
but it is not uite consummately excellent.
The Master said:
"Someone who when in a high position is not tolerant,
someone who in his practice of ritual propriety does not show respectful diligence,
someone who in handling funerals does not show genuine grief,
how could I (or: one) take the time to even look at him carefully? (He is beyond the pale.)"
The Master said:
"As for neighbourhoods, the Good people are the most admirable thing.
Given the choice, if one does not take one's place among those who are Good,
how can one gain a proper understanding of things?"
The Master said:
"If someone is not Good
he cannot for long remain in straightened circumstances,
and he cannot possibly for long remain in a mood of delight.
He who is Good finds his ultimate peace in Goodness;
he who is intelligent sees the benefit in Goodness.
The Master said:
"Only the Good
has the ability to be properly fond of others
has the ability to properly dislike others.
The Master said:
"If one's mind is really bent on Goodness,
there is no wickedness in one."
The Master said:
"Wealth and high status:
such things are what men desire.
But if it cannot be done in accordance with the Way
one does not settle for them.
Poverty and low status:
such things are what men dislike.
But if it cannot be done in accordance with the right Way
one does not keep away from these.
If a gentleman keeps away from Goodness
how can he establish a name for himself?
The gentleman will not go against Goodness for as long as the time of a meal.
When in a hurry he is sure to keep to such behaviour.
When stumbling he is sure to keep to such behaviour.
The Master said:
"I have never seen anyone who is properly fond of what is Good
or who hates what is not Good.
As for being really fond of what is Good
there is nothing that is to be valued higher than this;
as for hating what is not good
that must constitute Goodness.
One does not allow that which is not Good to change or affect one's person.
Is there a person who can use his strength on Goodness for one single day?
I for my part have never seen anyone whose strength would be insufficient for that.
Perhaps these exist, but I for my part have never seen such a person.
The Master said:
"In men's transgressions
they each conform to their group.
If one carefully observes one's transgressions
then one will understand Goodness [or lack of the same in others].
The Master said:
"If in the morning one learns about the Way,
then, supposing one dies that evening, that will be quite all right."
The Master said:
"If a gentleman aspires to the Way
but he considers poor clothing or poor food as disgraceful,
then he is not quite worth entering into discussions with."
The Master said:
"The man of character, in his relation to the world,
is without predilections
and is without prohibitions,
it is with what is right that he takes sides.
The Master said:
"The gentleman is preoccupied with virtue,
the petty man is preoccupied with his place of origin;
the gentleman is preoccupied with punishments (for misconduct),
the petty man is preoccupied with generosity."
The Master said:
"If one orientates oneself completely towards profit in one's actions
one will arouse much resentment."
"Can one use polite deference in running a state?
Well, what should be the problem?
But if one is unable use polite deference in running a state
how can one speak of ritual propriety?"
The Master said:
"One does not worry about not having a position
one worries about that through which one would get established in a position;
one does not worry about no one properly appreciating one,
one seeks to become worthy of being properly appreciated.
The Master said:
"Tell you something, Shēn!
My Way is one, and it is all-pervasive."
Zēngzǐ said:
"Yes."
When the master had left
the adherents said:
"What did he mean?"
Zēngzǐ said:
"The Way of the Master
is loyal effort (for those above) and understanding fairness (to those below), that is all."
The Master said:
"The man of character derives his understanding from what is right,
the petty man derives his understanding from what is profitable."
The Master said:
"When one sees a worthy person one reflects on how one might equal it;
when one sees an unworthy person one inwardly examines oneself."
The Master said:
"In the service of one's father and mother, one remonstrates subtly.
When one finds one's basic aspirations are not followed
one still shows respect and does not go against one's parents.
One makes strenuous efforts but shows no resentment."
The Master said:
"While one's father and mother are alive
one does not go on long pleasure trips.
If one does go on a pleasure trip, it is bound to be to a certain fixed place."
The Master said:
"If after three years one has nowhere introduced changes to the Way of one's father
that can be called filial piety."
The Master said:
"One's father's and mother's age
one must remember.
On the one hand one is pleased,
on the other hand one is afraid."
The Master said:
"When in ancient times people did not come out with public commitments
this was because they were ashamed that their persons might not live up to them."
The Master said:
"Those who, through keeping to the main thing, get things wrong
are few."
The Master said:
"The man of character desires to be reticent in his public promises or commitments
and efficient in his action."
The Master said:
"Virtue is not isolated,
of necessity it has its neighbours."
Zǐyǒu said:
"If in serving one's ruler one is fussy
then in fact one will suffer public disgrace;
if with friends one is fussy
then in fact one will be estranged from them."
The Master commented on Gōngyè Cháng:
"He is a suitable person to be given a wife.
He may have been fettered in prison,
but that was not his fault."
He gave him his daughter in marriage.
The Master commented on Nán Róng:
"When the Way prevailed in the land he was not cast aside,
and when the Way did not prevail in the land
he was able to avoid physical punishment or execution."
And he gave him his elder brother's daughter in marriage.
The Master commented on Zǐjiàn:
"A real man of character, this person!
If there were no such thing as a gentlemen in Lǔ,
how could this man have chosen this course of action?"
Zǐgòng asked:
"As for me, what am I like?"
The Master said:
"You are an instrument for use by others!"
He said:
"What kind of an instrument of use for others?"
The Master:
"You are a precious grain vessel of the húlián type!"
Someone said:
"That man Yōng is Good, but he is inarticulate."
The Master said:
"What use is there for articulateness?
If one stops people with the tricks of the mouth
one will often incur the hatred of others.
I am not so sure that he is good,
but what use has he for articulateness?"
The Master ordered Qìdiāo Kāi to take office.
The disciple answered politely:
"For this I cannot quite muster the confidence."
The Master was pleased.
The Master said:
"The Way is not being put into practise.
I'll get on a raft and float on the seas.
The one who would follow me,
that must be Yóu, mustn't it?"
Zǐlù, when he heard this, was delighted.
The Master said:
"That man Yóu is more prone to bravery than I.
But we cannot find the necessary timber (for that raft) anywhere!"
Mèng Wǔbó asked:
"Is Zǐlù good?"
The Master said:
"I am not sure he is."<2>
He asked the same question again.
The Master said:
"As for that man Yóu
in a state of one thousand chariots
he can be made to administer the military taxes.
But I do not know whether he is Good."
"How about that man Qiú?"
The Master said:
"As for Qiú,
in a city of a thousand Houses<3>
or in a family estate<4> with one hundred chariots
he can be made the steward,
but I do not know that he is Good."
"How about that man Chì?"
The Master said:
"As for that man Chì, girded with his sash, he stands in court
and he can be made to conduct talks<2> with guests,<1>
but I do not know that he is Good."
The Master said to Zigòng:
"Between you and Hui,
who is superior?"
He replied politely:
"As for me,
how would I presume to aspire to equal Hui?
As for Hui, when he has heard one thing, he thereby understands ten,
while I, when I have heard one thing, I understand two things."
The Master said:
"Yes, you are not up to him.
I and you, we are not up to him."
Zǎi Yú was sleeping during the daytime.
The Master said:
"Rotton wood cannot be carved,
A wall made of dung and mud cannot be properly plastered.
Regarding Yú, in one's dealing with him, what is there to apply one's strictures to?"
The Master said:
"In the beginning, in relation to others,
I listened to their promises and had faith in their performance;
now, in relation to others,
I listen to their pronouncements and observe their performance.
In relation to Yú, dealing with him, I have thus mended my ways.
The Master said:
"I have never met anyone who has firm convictions."
Someone responded to this:
"How about Shēn Chéng?"
The Master said:
"That man Chéng is full of lusts.
How can be get to count as firm?"
Zigòng said:
"What one does not want others to do to oneself,
this one does not want to do to others either."
The Master said:
"My friend,
this is not what you live up to."
Zigòng said:
"The Master's cultivated public accomplishments
one may hear about;
but the Master's pronouncements on human nature and the Way of Heaven,
these one cannot get to hear about."
When Zǐlù learnt something
then, if he was not quite able to carry it out into practice,
there was nothing he was more terrified of than learning it.
Zǐgòng asked:
"Why is Kǒng Wénzǐ called wén "cultivated"?"
The Master said:
"He is nimble and likes to learn new things,
he is not ashamed to consult people of lower station,
that is why he is called wén "cultivated".
The Master commented on Zǐchǎn:
"He possessed the proper way of the gentleman on four points:
in comporting himself he is polite;
in serving his superiors he is respectful;
in looking after the people he is generous;
in deploying the people he shows rectitude."
The Master said:
"Yàn Pingzhòng is good at cultivating relations with others.
In the long run these respect him."
The Master said:
"When Zàng Wénzhòng staid in Cài;
he had mountain patterns on the column connectors and seaweed patterns on the beams,
How good, then, was his knowledge?"
Zǐzhāng asked:
"Prime Minister Zǐwén served three times as Prime Minister,
but he never had a pleased expression on his face;
he was thrice removed,
but he never had a resentful expression on his face.
As for the administration of the old prime minister
he was sure to inform the new prime minister about it.
What are we to make of that?"
The Master said:

"Is that the disciple of Confucius from Lǔ?"
Zǐlù replied politely:
"Yes."
He continued:
"It is all one great mess, this,
the whole world is a case in point.
Who then is to change the world for a new one?
Come to think of it, you, instead of becoming a follower of this gentleman who avoids other people,
why don't you follow someone who avoids the world altogether?"
And he kept covering the seed with earth as he spoke.
Zǐlù went away to report on what happened.
The Master was dazed and he said:
"One cannot flock together with birds and beasts, you know.
If I do not associate with these (disorientated) people
whom am I to associate with?
If the Way prevailed in the world
I wouldn't get involved to change it. "
Zǐlù was following along with Confucius, but was lagging behind.
He met an old man
who has carrying a baslet over his back on a pole.
Zǐlù asked:
"Have you seen the Master?"
The old man said:
"He does not exert his four limbs,
the five kinds of grain he cannot tell the difference of,
How can he serve as your master?"
Sticking his staff in the ground he started weeding.
Zilù stood there with folded arms.
The old man made Zǐlù stay for a night.
He killed a chicken, prepared broomcorn millet and gave him a meal.
He also introduced his two sons [to the visitor].
The next day
Zǐlù went on his way to report the matter.
The Master said:
"He is one who lies low."
He sent Zǐlù to go back and visit him,
but when he arrived, the man had gone.
Zǐlù said:
"Refusing to take up official functions shows a lack of moral rectitude.
The rules governing relative seniority
must not be given up;
the rules of rectitude between ruler and minister,
how could one abandon these?
He desired to keep his person unsullied.
but he ruined the fundamental social relations.
When the gentleman takes public office
it is in order to put into practice moral rectitude.
That the Way is not being practised
we can already tell [from this episode]."
Ordinary citizens who withdrew were:
Bó Yí, Shū Qí, Yúzhòng, Yíyì, Zhūzhāng, Liǔxià Huì, Shàolián.
The Master said:
"They did not lower their aspirations
and did not expose their persons to humiliations.
Such were Bóyí and Shūqí, were they not?"
Referring to Liǔxià Huì and Shàolián:
"They lowered their aspirations and did humiliate their persons,
their public pronouncements were in accordance with the fundamental social relations,
their behaviour was in accordance with their planning.
I suppose they just did that, that is all."
Referring to Yúzhòng and Yíyì:
"They lived in seclusion and came up with unrestrained pronouncements.
Their persons, inside, were undefiled,
when dismissed they adapted.
I, on the other hand, am different from people like these.
I in no way approve or disapprove of these."
Grand musicmaster Zhí went to Qí,
Second Course Gān went to Chǔ,
Third Course Liáo went to Cài,
Fourth Course Quē went to Qín,
Drummer Fāngshū threw himself the Yellow River,
Tambour Player Wǔ threw himself the River Hàn,
Junior Master Yáng and music stone player Xiāng threw himself the sea.
The Duke of Zhōu told the Duke of Lǔ:
"The gentleman will not show generosity to his kin,
he will not cause the powerful ministers to be resentful that they are not used;
Old friends he will not dismiss without substantial reason
and he will never seek complete performance of duties from one single person."
Under the Zhōu there were eight real gentlemen:
Bódá, Bódí, Zhòngtū, Zhònghū, Shūyè, Shūxià, Jì Suí, Jì Guí.
Zǐzhāng said:
"When the gentleman sees a dangerous situation he risks his life,
when he sees possible profit he thinks of moral principles,
when he sacrifices he thinks of proper devotion,
when he conducts funerals he thinks of grief.
I suppose that is definitely acceptable."
Zǐzhāng said:
"If in holding onto virtue one is not magnanimous,
if in keeping faithfully to the Way one is not dependable,
how can one be taken to exist (morally),
or how can one be taken not to exist (morally)? [One is morally neither here nor there. ??????]
Zǐxià's follower asked Zǐzhāng about human relations
Zǐzhāng asked:
"What does Zǐxià maintain concerning this subject?"
He replied politely:
"Zǐxià says:
'Those who are acceptable, associate with them,
and as for those who are not acceptable, keep them abay."
Zǐzhāng said:
"Very strange, this thing I heard:
'The superior man honours the talented and is tolerant with the masses;
He commends those who are excellent and sympathise with the incompetent.
Suppose one is superbly talented,
then in one's relation to others, whom will one fail to be tolerant towards?
Suppose one is without talent,
then others will reject one.
But why should one reject others?"
Zǐxià said:
"Even in matters of small moral significance
there are invariably things that should be carefully observed;
In aiming for distant things he (identified only in the next line!) is afraid to get bogged down,
that is why the superior man will not engage in such projects.
Zǐxià said:
"To be aware every day of what one does not have,
and every month not to forget what one has learnt to do
that can definitely be called being fond of study!"
Zǐxià said:
"To study broadly and to be sturdy in one's aspirations
to consult others incisively and to think concretely:
there is Goodness in this."
Zǐxià said:
"All craftsmen stay in their shops to achieve their tasks.
The superior man engages in study in order to reach the right Way."
Zǐxià said:
"When the petty man makes a mistake he will invariably try to make it look good."
Zǐxià said:
"In the superior man there are three variations:
when one looks at him from a distance he appears all formidable;
when one gets close to him he appears warm-hearted;
when one listens to his pronouncements he appears fierce."
Zǐxià said:
"The superior man will only work the people hard after he has achieved trusty good faith,
for if he never shows his trustiness
then people will consider that he is bullying them.
only when he has achieved trusty good faith will he remonstrate,
for when he is never in trusty good faith
then people will consider that he is slandering them.
Zǐxià said:
"If in matters of all-important virtue one does not overstep one's bounds,
then if in minor virtues there are minor deviations that is acceptable."
Zǐyóu said:
"As for Zǐxià's little disciples
when it comes to washing and sweeping, and the making of spontaneous answers
and when it comes to moving forward and withdrawing, they are acceptable.
However, these are marginal details.
When it comes to what is fundamental then that they are lacking.
How can that be?"
Zǐxià, when he heard this, said:
"Ah!
Yányóu is wrong.
As for the Way of the superior man
To whom it is transmitted first
he will tire of it last.
It can be compared to shrubs and trees,
one holds them apart so that they are distinguished.
As for the Way of the superior man
how can it be slandered?
As for a person who has both beginning and end, [i.e. who "hangs together in this way"]
I suppose, is only the sage."
Zǐxià said:
"If one excels in public employment then one engages in study;
if one excels in study then one gets public employment."
Zǐyóu said:
"When mourning gets to the stage of real grief then it stops."
Zǐyóu said:
"As for my friend Zhāng,
does things that are hard to do (i.e. is someone whose level is hard to achieve).
And yet he is not quite Good."
Zēngzǐ said:
"How elevated and dignified Zhāng is.
It is hard to count as Good side by side with him."
Zēngzǐ said:
"I have heard it from our Master:
'By necessity man never succeeds all by himself, -
or if at all on the occasion of funeral arrangements for his parents (when he is bereaved of his natural support)."
Zēngzǐ said:
"I have heard it from our Master:
'As for the filial piety of Mèng Zhuāngzǐ
the other parts are possibly things that can be competently mastered
but his not changing his father's ministers or his administration,
such behaviour is indeed difficult to master competently.'"
The Mèng clan sent Yángfú to act as Master of the Gentlemen
and they consulted Zēngzǐ on this.
Zēngzǐ said:
"The leadership has lost the right Way
and the people have been disunited for a long time.
But when gets the facts straight
then one should feel sympathy (with these people) and not be pleased with oneself (i.e. with this)."
Zǐgòng said:
"The wickedness in Zhòu
was not as bad as all that.
That is why the superior man hates to live among the vulgar people,
since all the wicked people of the world converge there.
Zǐgòng said:
"When a superior man makes a mistake
that is like the sun or the moon eclipsing.
When he makes a mistake
everybody sees it;
when he makes up for it
everybody is full of admiration for that."
Gōngsūn Cháo of Wèy consulted Zǐgòng saying:
"How could Confucius have studied with anyone (since he was such a unique sage)?"
Zǐgòng said:
"The Way of Wén and Wǔ
have not yet fallen to the ground.
It subsists among the people.
Men of talent keep in mind important parts,
men without talent keep in mind the unimportant parts.
But all of them have the Way of Wén and Wǔ.
Our Master, why should he not have studied?
And yet, surely: what permanent teacher should he have had?"
Shūsūn Wǔshū told a dignitary at court:
"Zǐgòng is more talented than Confucius."
Zǐfú Jǐnggó reported this to Zǐgòng.
Zǐgòng said:
"Let us compare this to the surrounding walls of a house.
My walls reach up to the shoulders
and one can glimpse the beautiful things inside the home.
Our Master's walls are several rèn high,
and if one does not get to enter the place through the right gate
one is unable to see the beautiful things in the ancestral tempels
or the wealth of all the offices.
Probably those who find the right gate are few.
When it comes to our Master speaking as he does
is that not fair enough?"
Shūsūn Wǔshū maligned Confucius.
Zǐgòng said:
"I think nothing of this.
Confucius cannot be maligned.
The most talented among other people
are little mounds
and one can still leap across.
Confucius is like the sun or moon
and one can in no way leap across.
Even if someone were wanting to cut himself off from these,
what damage can they do to the sun or the moon?"
More and more one sees that this man does not know how to gage his own limitations.
Chén Zǐqín said to Zǐgòng:
"You are being polite!
How should Confucius be a better man than you?"
Zǐgòng said:
"The superior man will, on account of one public pronouncement, be taken to be wise,
and on account of one public pronouncement he will taken to be unwise.
One's public pronouncements one must be very careful about.
Our Master's being beyond our reach
is like Heaven being impossible to climb up to on stairs.
If our Master were to gain control of a land or of a clan
this would illustrate the following:
'When he establishes something it stands,
when he guides something along it works,
when he comforts people they flock to him,
when he activates them they act in harmony.
While alive he shines with glory,
when dead he is mourned with real grief.
How could he be reached?"
Yáo said:
"Oh,
you, Shùn!
The calendrical numbers rest on your shoulders.
Really grasp the centre of it.
If all within the Four Seas gets into trouble
then the benefits of Heaven will forever have ended."
Shùn also commanded Yǔ along the same lines.
"I, the little one, Lǚ
have the audacity to offer a reddish black male
and I have the audacity to announce to the openly to the august Lord
those who are guilty I shall not presume to let go free,
the Lord's servitors I shall not keep in the dark,
and the choice will lie with the Lord's heart.
If in my person there is guilt,
do not act on this against the myriad regions.
When the myriad regions are guilty of crimes
the responsibility is on my person.
"The Zhōu made generous gifts
and those who were excellent, these got enriched."
We may have the Zhōu blood relatives,
but they are not as good as Good men.
If the Hundred Families make mistakes,
responsibility for this resides in me alone.
Pay careful attention to the scales and measures,
pay close attention to the laws and fixed procedures,
reestablish offices that have been abandoned,
then the administration in the Four Regions will run smoothly as a result of this.
Raise up states that have been destroyed,
continue interrupted continuities of generations,
lift up uprooted populations,
and the people of the world will turn their hearts to you.
What one makes one's priority:
Nourishment, proper funerals and decent sacrifices for the people.
If one is tolerant one will win over the multitides,
and if one keeps good faith then the people will allow themselves to be employed by one.
If one is skilful then one will have achievements,
if one is public-spirited then others will be pleased."
Zǐzhāng asked Confucius:
"What does one have to do
so that one can run an administration properly?"
The Master said:
"Honour the five beautiful things,
block off the four ugly things,
then indeed you can run an administration properly."
Zǐzhāng asked:
"What do you call 'the five beautiful things?'"
The Master said:
"The superior man is generous but not extravagant in expenditure;
he is hard-working but not given to resentment;
he has desires but is not greedy;
he is self-confident but not arrogant;
he has natural authority but he is not fierce."
Zǐzhāng said:
"What do you mean by 'he is generous but not extravagant in his expenditure'?"
The Master said:
"If one adapts to what the people regard as profitable and treats that as profitable,
then indeed is that not a case of being generous but not extravagant in one's expenditure?
If one choses those who deserve to be rewarded and rewards them
then who else will be full of resentment?
If one wishes one had Goodness one obtains Goodness,
how should one go on to be greedy?
If the superior man, no matter whether he deals with a large group or a small one,
no matter whether he deals with small matters or large ones,
will never dare to be negligent,
then will he not surely be self-confident without being arrogant?
The superior man will adjust his clothes and his headdress properly
and he will ensure that his glance invites veneration.
If he is stern and others will look at him from a distance and stand in awe of him,
then will he not surely have natural authority without being fierce?"
Zǐzhāng said:
"What do you call 'the four ugly things'?"
The Master said:
"Failing to train people properly and then killing them is called ruthlessness;
failing to warn people and looking for things to be completed properly is called violence;
be negligent in one's orders but insist on performance in time is chicanery;
??If in any case?? one gives something to others,
and in the giving out of it one is stingy,
then one is called a mere official.
The Master said:
"If one does not understand Fate
then one does not have what it takes to become a man of superior character;
If one does not understand ritual propriety
then one does not have what it takes to get established;
If one does not properly understand language
then one does not have what it takes to understand men properly."
